--- title: "Statistical Concepts" --- # Assigment 2 ## Assignment 2.1 ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_862fe37b30bbf93e4316c71f6b456508'} ```{.r .cell-code} #load libraries library(dplyr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #> #> filter, lag ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #> #> intersect, setdiff, setequal, union ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Load the data from random_vars.rds file data <- readRDS("data/random_vars.rds") # Replace 'path_to_your_folder' with the actual path # View the loaded data View(data) # Compute expected value, variance, and standard deviation for each variable summary_stats <- data.frame( Variable = colnames(data), Expected_Value = sapply(data, mean), Variance = sapply(data, var), Standard_Deviation = sapply(data, sd) ) # View summary statistics summary_stats ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ## Assignment 2.2 Standard deviation provides insights into the variability of individual variables, comparing relationships between 'age' and 'income' would benefit more from measures like covariance and correlation to understand how these variables are related or associated with each other but comparing covariance is not easy. Where as in correlation, we get values between -1 and 1 which provides a standardized measure to interpret the strength and direction of linear relationship between age and income. ## Assignment 2.3 ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_121c44dbd7acf3e695d8d864bf9de228'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Compute expected value, variance, and standard deviation for each variable summary_stats <- data.frame( Variable = colnames(data), Covariance = sapply(data, function(x) sapply(data, function(y) cov(x, y))), Correlation = sapply(data, function(x) sapply(data, function(y) cor(x, y))) ) # View summary statistics summary_stats ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: It is easier to interpret correlation as compared to covarience as discussed above. ## Assignment 2.4 ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_4ed481cadcfea5009df879063e183466'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Calculate conditional expected values for income based on age ranges conditional_expected_value <- data %>% summarize( E_income_age_18 = mean(filter(., age <= 18)$income), E_income_age_18_65 = mean(filter(., age >= 18 & age < 65)$income), E_income_age_65 = mean(filter(., age >= 65)$income) ) conditional_expected_value ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: :::
